description: Show Linux Process information as captured by  https://github.com/ncabatoff/process-exporter  designed for PMM

panels.title: Top processes by Total CPU cores used
Top processes by System CPU cores used

panels.description: Used Memory means the space process consumes in RAM plus space it consumes in the swap space. Note, this metric is different from Virtual Memory, which also includes virtual space which was assigned to the process but never really allocated.
panels.title: Top processes by Used  memory

panels.description: Resident Memory means the memory process (or technically group of processes) takes in physical RAM.  The "Proportional" means the method by how this consumption is counted. A single page in RAM sometimes is shared by multiple processes, and Proportional means it is divided up among all processes sharing it when memory allocation is accounted for rather than counted as part of every process. This ensures there is no double counting and you should not see total size of Resident memory for your processes well in excess of the physical memory you have.
panels.title: Top processes by Resident Memory

panels.description: Virtual Memory is the virtual address space that was allocated to process. In some cases, it will be close to memory used, and in other cases, it may be very different.
panels.title: Top processes by Virtual memory

panels.description: Swapped Memory shows us which processes are swapped out and by how much.  I would pay special attention to this graph because if the Swap Activity panel shows serious IO going on, this means system performance might be significantly impacted. If unused processes are swapped out, or even some unused portions of the processes, it is not the problem.
panels.title: Top processes by Swapped Memory
Top processes by number of  processes instances
Top processes by number of threads

panels.description: A high number of Voluntary Context Switches (hundreds of thousands and millions per second) may indicate heavy contention, or it may just correspond to a high number of requests being served by the process, as in many architectures starting/stopping request handling requires a context switch.
panels.title: Top Processes by Voluntary Context Switches

panels.description: A high number of Non-Voluntary Context Switches, on the other hand, can correspond to not having enough CPU available with processes moved off CPU by the scheduler when they have exceeded their allotted time slice, or for other reasons.
panels.title: Top Processes by  Non-Voluntary Context Switches

panels.description: File Descriptors show us the global limit of the file descriptors allowed in the operating system as well as for individual processes.  Running out of file descriptors for a whole system is really bad, as you will have many things start failing at random. Although on modern, powerful systems, the limit is so high you rarely hit this problem.
panels.title: Top processes by Open File Descriptors

panels.description: The limit of files process can open still applies so it is very helpful to see which processes require a lot of file descriptors (by number) and also how this number compares to the total number of descriptors allowed for the process.
panels.title: Top processes by File Descriptor Usage Percent

panels.description: Major page faults are relatively expensive, typically causing disk IO when they happen.
panels.title: Top processes by Major Page Faults

panels.description: Minor page faults are less expensive, corresponding to accessing pages that are not mapped to the given process address space but otherwise are in memory.  Minor page faults are less expensive, requiring a switch to kernel mode and for the kernel to do some housekeeping.
panels.title: Top processes by Minor Page Faults
Top of processes waiting on IO

title: System Processes Metrics
